Author: habs
Content:
"There was of course no way of knowing whether you were being watched at any given moment. How often, or on what system, the Thought Police plugged in on any individual wire was guesswork. It was even conceivable that they watched everybody all the time. But at any rate they could plug in your wire whenever they wanted to. You had to live-did live, from habit that became instinct-in the assumption that every sound you made was overheard, and, except in darkness, every movement scrutinized."

-1984

Title: Internet Access Without Electricity, Connectivity or Phone Services.

Author: silencio
Content: too slow for recent content like tv shows. i typically find torrents of the tv shows i watch right after they finish airing on the east coast and download them even quicker.

Author: blasdel
Content:
I agree with you that people liked scaling using a single big machine back then, and Sun had the biggest and best machines (and still does to some extent).

The problem is more that a ton of those people didn't actually need to scale.

Author: astrec
Content:
Try Komodo - quite a good package. PyDev is good if you're already an eclipse user. I hear good things about Kate.

I'm an Emacs user myself - the power is addictive.

Author: garrydanger
Content:
Ever since I first watched "ghost in the shell" years ago I've been a bit scared of a time when we will be able to plug our brain into a computer network... with the risk of getting it hacked.

I mean, you could always refuse to jack yourself in but I doubt I could.

Author: astrec
Title: The $62,550 machine no one bought - Honeywell's Kitchen Computer remembered

Author: pchristensen
Content:
...since no one knows how to program AI

Do you think no one will ever figure this out? There's a bunch of stuff that no one used to know how to do but is common now. Why would AI be any different?

Author: yters
Content:
That's why Eliezer Yudkowsky is working on friendly AI.

http://yudkowsky.net/

Though, that still doesn't rule out people misusing friendly AI against each other. Say some megalomaniac thinks it'd be much more convenient to have a bunch of friendly AIs around than a human population prone to revolt. In that case, friendly AI is not so great since it disrupts the power balance.

Author: janm
Content:
Transaction Processing: Concepts and Techniques (Jim Gray & Andreas Reuter) isn't just one of the best database textbooks, it is one of the best computer science textbooks. It is an Important Work.

On the other books, it depends on what you want. Alternatives to Date include Jeffrey Ullman, "Principles of Database and knowledge-base Systems" and "Foundations of Databases" by Abiteboul, Hull and Vianu.

As an introductory book, I like Database: Principles, Programming, Performance by Patrick O'Neil.

For more on transaction processing, as well as Jim Gray there is Philip Bernstein, eg "Principles of Transaction Processing".

Following the references is a lot of fun; see where you end up.
